thread.title: Photos of mansion on Seattle's billionaire hot spot Mercer Island

author: Christopher Dilella
title: Photos of mansion on Seattle's billionaire hot spot Mercer Island
text:
44 Mins Ago | 01:01
Just outside of Seattle is a ritzy enclave called Mercer Island, and it's home to some of Seattle's billionaires. Microsoft co-founder and NFL Seahawks owner Paul Allen (net worth: $19.8 billion ) has a mansion there, as does Starbucks executive chairman Howard Schultz (net worth: $2.8 billion ). Michael Walmsley | Avenue Properties Exterior view
Nestled on the isle in Lake Washington is a three-story modern mega-mansion, currently on the market for $15 million.
Take a look inside. Michael Walmsley | Avenue Properties Dining room
"This is a pinnacle piece on the lake," says broker Moya Skillman with Avenue Properties, which holds the listing . "It's located in a great community which has attracted many CEOs from all the major companies in the area."
Built in 2002, every detail inside the nearly 10,000-square-foot residence was hand-selected by the owners â€” from the African hardwoods to the limestone on the living room fireplace, explains Skillman. Michael Walmsley | Avenue Properties Living room.
The property has eight bathrooms and seven bedrooms, including the luxe master suite with picture perfect views of the lake. Michael Walmsley | Avenue Properties Master suite
On the estate's lower level is the media room, sauna and wine cellar, which can hold more than 5,000 bottles. Michael Walmsley | Avenue Properties Wine room.
"This owner enjoyed hosting wine tastings when entertaining friends," explains Skillman. "There are hundreds of wineries [in the Pacific Northwest] and we have a big population of wine enthusiasts." Michael Walmsley | Avenue Properties Pool and dock
Out back is the property's infinity pool and a private dock, which sits on 124 feet of waterfront land. Michael Walmsley | Avenue Properties Entrance way
"It's very rare to have such a large piece of property on the lake," says Skillman. "Estates like this only come along once in a generation."
Want more mansion insipiration? Watch CNBC's "Secret Lives of the Super Rich" on Apple TV and On-Demand. show chapters
